title: Cat. 111.3  Three People, a Mask, a Fox and a Bird, 1899
publication_title: Gauguin Paintings, Sculpture, and Graphic Works at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Printed by Pola Gauguin (Danish, born France, 1883–1961)  
Published by Christian Cato, Copenhagen  
Three People, a Mask, a Fox and a Bird, headpiece for Le sourire (The Smile)  
1899, printed and published 1921  
Only state  
Wood-block print in black ink on ivory China paper; 103 × 184 mm (image); 268 × 425 mm (sheet)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, the Joseph Brooks Fair Collection, 1924.1194  
Guérin 75, Kornfeld 58 D,b  
For the verso, see fig. 111.3.1

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section technical_report" id="technical_report">Gauguin took the block that he used for Mahana atua (Day of the God) (cat. 80) with him when he left Paris to return to Tahiti in 1895. In 1899, as part of his endeavor to publish a monthly periodical, he used the back of the block to carve this and another headpiece for Le sourire (The Smile): Fox, Busts of Two Women, and a Rabbit (cat. 120). The block was carved so that the vignettes face each other; they abut along their bottom edges. The commercially available wood-block was manufactured with a series of four screws to hold smaller segments of boxwood together. The voids left by the apertures from this assemblage were appropriated by the artist to add his initials and to inscribe numbers. The block is extant and in the collection of the National Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C. (fig. 111.3.2). This impression was printed and published posthumously by Pola Gauguin in 1921.

The impression is richly printed in black ink. The combination of meticulous inking, careful wiping, and use of a smooth, absorbent China paper conducive to lifting the ink from the block’s surface resulted in a crisp, highly detailed impression. Given that the block was manufactured with screws, it appears that care was taken to tighten and realign the three segments so that, when printed, the joins were properly aligned.

The signature at lower left is prominently represented in the posthumous impression. Additional stray marks appear at bottom center where the block was most heavily inked; they are not readily apparent in Gauguin’s impressions, although some evidence of them does appear in the November 1899 issue (cat. 109) of Le sourire.

This posthumous impression was printed on a smooth ivory China paper, the paper favored for printing all of the prints in the posthumous edition.

103 × 184 mm (image); 268 × 425 mm (sheet)

The print is in sound, stable condition.  
Mary Broadway and Harriet K. Stratis

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section provenance" id="provenance">Sold by Thomas W. Schreiner, New York, to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1924.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section exhibitions" id="exhibitions">Houston, Contemporary Arts Museum, Shadow and Substance: The Shadow Theater of Montmartre and Modern Art, Mar. 3–Apr. 1, 1956, no cat. no.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section references" id="references">Contemporary Arts Museum, Houston, Shadow and Substance: The Shadow Theater of Montmartre and Modern Art, exh. cat. (Contemporary Arts Museum, 1956), n.pag., no cat no.

Elizabeth Mongan, Eberhard W. Kornfeld, and Harold Joachim, Paul Gauguin: Catalogue Raisonné of His Prints, with assistance of Christine H. Stauffer (Galerie Kornfeld, 1988), p. 223, cat. 58.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section other_documentation" id="other_documentation">Signed lower right, below image, in pale silvery-purple graphite (copy pencil?): Pola Gauguin imp

Inscribed lower left, below image, in pale silvery-purple graphite (copy pencil?): Paul Gauguin fait

Inscribed upper left, above image, in pale silvery-purple graphite (copy pencil?): no 50

Inscribed lower left, in graphite: A I C / 24.1194 / 6386

Collection stamp in oval, center, in brown ink: THE ART / INSTITUTE OF / CHICAGO

The nature of the media and their application, as well as the condition of the artwork, were assessed through visual examination using normal, transmitted, and raking light; microscope magnification (80–300×); and ultraviolet-light examination (254 and 365 nm).

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 111.3 Three People, a Mask, a Fox and a Bird, headpiece for Le sourire (The Smile), 1899, printed and published 1921.

fig. 111.3.2 Paul Gauguin (French, 1848–1903). Left, Two Title Pages for “Le sourire,” verso, in or after 1895. Right, Mahana atua, recto, 1894/95. Woodcut block; 20 × 28 cm (7 7/8 × 11 in.). National Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C., Rosenwald Collection, 1943.3.1726.b, a.

fig. 111.3.1 Verso of Gauguin’s Three People, a Mask, a Fox and a Bird, headpiece for Le sourire (The Smile) (1899, printed and published 1921). The Art Institute of Chicago, 1924.1194.

</section>
